metadata.case_name: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao & Ors. v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation & Ors.

facts.text: Appellants were carrying on motor transport business for several years in Krishna District in the State of Andhra Pradesh.
Shri Guru Pershad, General Manager of the State Transport Undertaking, published a scheme for nationalization of motor transport in the said State.
Objections to the proposed scheme were invited by the State Government, and the appellants filed objections.
On December 26, 1957, the Secretary in charge of the Transport Department gave a personal hearing to the objectors and heard representations on behalf of the State Transport Undertaking.
The Chief Minister approved the scheme, published in Andhra Pradesh Gazette dated January 9, 1958, effective from January 10, 1958.
Andhra Pradesh Road Transport Corporation formed under Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950, took over and proceeded to implement the scheme.
Appellants moved Supreme Court under Art. 32, which quashed the approval order on grounds related to hearing by Secretary, dated November 5, 1958.
Government issued notices for personal hearing by Chief Minister on December 9, 1958; objectors could file further objections by November 30, 1958.
Chief Minister heard objectors and Corporation, passed orders dated December 19, 1958, rejecting objections and approving scheme; published December 22, 1958.
On December 23, 1958, Corporation applied to Regional Transport Authority (RTA) for permits and eliminating private permits.

RTA passed orders on December 24, 1958, rendering appellants' permits ineffective from December 24, 1958, issuing permits to Corporation; communicated same day, directing stop plying from December 25, 1958.
Appellants filed writ petitions in Andhra Pradesh High Court under Art. 226 to quash Government and RTA orders; dismissed by Division Bench on March 5, 1959.
Appellants filed affidavits alleging Chief Minister initiated scheme and was biased; counter-affidavit denied, stating scheme initiated by Guru Pershad, Corporation autonomous.
Newspaper extracts (Exhibits IV, V, VI, IX, X) purporting speeches by Chief Minister supporting nationalization; not proved by affidavits from witnesses.
Appellants withdrew vehicles post-RTA order; Corporation vehicles plying on routes.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Chief Minister was disqualified from hearing objections due to official bias as Minister in charge of transport or personal bias from acts and speeches.
Whether the Regional Transport Authority complied with Rule 11 by giving due notice before rendering permits ineffective.

petitioner_arguments.text: Chief Minister disqualified like Secretary per previous Gullapalli judgment, as in charge of transport portfolio; party cannot be judge in own cause.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principles of natural justice; Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation

petitioner_arguments.text: Chief Minister's acts (initiating scheme) and speeches showed personal bias against private operators.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Doctrine of bias: no man shall be judge in own cause; justice must manifestly seem to be done

petitioner_arguments.text: RTA rendered permits ineffective without due notice as per Rule 11.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 11 of Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Rules; s.68F(2) Motor Vehicles Act

respondent_arguments.text: Distinction between official bias inherent in statutory duty and personal bias; no proof of personal bias.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Statutory authorization qualifies doctrine of bias

respondent_arguments.text: Chief Minister not part of Transport Department; Corporation autonomous; scheme initiated by Guru Pershad.
Newspaper reports not proved; speeches reflect policy only.

court_reasoning.text: Principles of bias apply to quasi-judicial functions: no man judge in own cause; justice must seem to be done. Statutory duty does not override unless expressly authorized.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act does not authorize Government to initiate scheme and judge; visualizes Government as neutral judge.

court_reasoning.text: Distinction between Secretary (part of department) and Chief Minister (primarily responsible, but not part); previous judgment accepted CM's competence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants cannot reopen after previous judgment.

court_reasoning.text: No proof Chief Minister initiated scheme or made biasing speeches; newspaper extracts unproved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Speeches reflect policy; no closed mind established.

court_reasoning.text: RTA violated Rule 11: no prior notice, only one day compliance; but technical defect, no practical utility to quash as scheme upheld, vehicles replaced.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court discretion under Art.226 rightly exercised.

holdings.text: Chief Minister not disqualified; no violation of natural justice.
RTA order defective for lack of due notice under Rule 11, but no interference warranted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation
precedents_cited.relevance: Previous stage quashed scheme due to Secretary's hearing; distinguished for Chief Minister

precedents_cited.case_name: The King v. Bath Compensation Authority
precedents_cited.relevance: No one can be party and judge; statute does not override natural justice unless clear
Statutory duty originating objection ok if within procedure; unlike active opposition

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writs filed; Governor acts on Minister advice; business rules

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 (as amended by Act 100 of 1956)
statutes_cited.relevance: Scheme preparation, approval, permit cancellation to implement scheme

statutes_cited.name: Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Formation of Corporation to implement scheme

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upholding High Court dismissal of writs; Chief Minister's hearing valid, no bias; RTA procedural defect overlooked as futile.

key_quotes.text: "no man shall be a judge in his own cause; justice should not only be done but manifestly and undoubtedly seem to be done."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principles of bias doctrine applied

key_quotes.text: "unless the legislature clearly and expressly ordained to the contrary, the principles of natural justice cannot be violated."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits statutory override of natural justice

key_quotes.text: "to interfere on a technical point of no practical utility is to strain at a gnat after swallowing a camel."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justification for not quashing RTA order despite defect
